data.title: Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon have one more son.

data.text:
In 1482, Isabella the Catholic gave birth to twin girls, Maria of Aragon and another girl who was stillborn. My query is this, let's say that the twin girl is actually a boy named Ferdinand after his father, and the boy is relatively healthy and lives into adulthood. If Juan, Prince of Asturias still dies in 1497, would Ferdinand junior marry Margaret of Austria in a mirror of Henry and Arthur to Catherine of Aragon, or would another marriage be sought for him? Consequently, regardless of the marriage, one imagines the presence of Ferdinand eases the worries of the Catholic monarchs once Juan is dead, for they've got another son to inherit their domains. Thus one imagines Ferdinand V does not remarry when his wife dies, thus leaving Germaine of Foix free to marry whoever she wishes. Ferdinand's existence also means the Habsburgs remain in the EMpire and the Low Countries rather than in Spain, thus freeing Spain from all those pesky entanglements.

Are there any other consequences that could emerge?

@Kellan Sullivan @The Professor @krieger @isabella @BlueFlowwer @Tyler96 @Zulfurium

Then in 1510 when Margaret has died he decides to stay away from Milan since he is tired of the whole thing. Naples is ruled peacefully by Spain, he marries Marguerite as part of a peace deal and a second chance of a son for the throne. Spain is out and he can focus on more domestic things and gets the infantes he desired.

The only issue with Margaret Habsburg as a wife is that she and John definitely consummated their marriage (she had a stillborn daughter, if I remember correctly). Katherine of Aragon and Henry VIII were allowed to marry because her marriage to Arthur was never consummated, thus he was never really her husband (sorry, Church of England fans). Cannon law is very strict on it's interpretation on marrying your brother's wife: if they slept together, it's a big no-no. That's why it was Henry VII's argument for an annulment when he was trying to get the Pope to annul his marriage to Katherine. The only way it could work for Margaret and Ferdinand 2.0 is moving up Juan's death or delaying his marriage to Margaret so they never consummate the marriage.
